text: every day people arrive at the cheetah
moyo Christian hospital and rural
Zimbabwe with chickens goats or saxo
peanuts to barter for doctor visits and
medicines we began to ask people to
bring things instead of money and so
they started bringing their crops the
hospital started seriously bartering in
2008 when Zimbabwe inflation rate had an
incredible 500 billion percent and the
local currency became worthless the
country has sent switched to the
American dollar but cash remains scarce
in the impoverished country side this
mission hospital continues to let its
patients barter even as other hospitals
collect fees in dollars only we quickly
came up with a priceless and a lot of
people brought pigs and turkeys and goes
Kathy McCarty a nurse from California
has run the hospital for 30 years the
staff of two doctors and 15 nurses see
about 6,000 patients a month we feel
very strongly that patients should pay
for something for their care because
they do have things that they can bring
with modest support from the government
this eighty-five bed hospital is short
of money like the people it serves and
the staff has become extremely
resourceful we do a lot of recycling we
use our gloves weary powder them and
weary sterilize them because it's
difficult to get gloves it's expensive
for our patients and they're still good
the second or third time around workers
sterilize other medical supplies in
cauldrons over an open fire and reuse
them they collect the instructions from
thousands of pill bottles for use as
toilet paper I separate the boxes from
the pills from the soon-to-be toilet
paper this becomes firewood these go to
our patients
these go to the bathroom at night during
frequent power outages nurses make their
rounds by flashlight for almost a year
the hospital did not have blood
available because it couldn't afford it
we operating within the back of your
mind you be thinking i tol a significant
blood loss what will happen so the
barter system has helped keep both the
patients and their hospital alive this
woman brought three gallons of peanuts
in the rural areas it's so difficult to
get money money is so scarce so that's
why I bring peanuts one bucket of
peanuts is more than enough to cover the
one dollar fee to see the doctor the
benefits of bartering to the hospital is
that we don't have to buy food for our
patients we have meat we have maize we
have the things that we can serve each
day with them the hospital's Chapel for
a thousand people is now filled with a
giant mountain of unshelled nuts they
are made into peanut butter that helps
feed the patients and saves the hospital
on the cost of meals we use the peanut
butter in the porridge we use the peanut
butter with bread at tea-time and we
have cut down tremendously on the amount
of food and things that we have to not
only bye-bye transport because we live
so far from any stores the hospital
survives on donations from American and
British churches we need about ten
thousand dollars a month to run the
hospital and some once we get that in
some months we don't get that but it
seems like whenever we really need it
God provides and it always comes through
Ellen keep right
despite their financial woes the
hospital's indomitable spirit continues
and life goes on in those above on a
recent morning this baby boy emerged
from his mother's womb but made no sound
until a few minutes later
